Passing data from Controller to View

There are three different ways to pass data:

1.       ViewData.Model =myobj used in View through This.Model

2.       View(myobj) used in View through This.Model

3.       ViewData[myobj]= myobj used in View through ViewData[myobj]

Notice that multiple data can be passed to the viewer at the same time, like:

                if (empees == null || empees.Count() == 0)

                    ViewData["Message"] = "No matched record found";

             return View(empees);

 

As you can see we are sending 2 diff data to the viewer and they can be used as follows

For empees:

 

 

Inherits="System.Web.Mvc.ViewPage<IEnumerable<JobRepoMVC.Models.Employee>>" %>

<% if (Model !=null )  foreach (var item in Model) { %>

 

For Message:

<p><%: ViewData["Message"] %></p>

 

Passing data from View to Controller

There are different ways to pass data:

1.1.    Query String

If we want to send it through the Query String, We should:

1.1.1. We need Html.BeginForm()

1.1.2. The following arguments should be sent through BeginForm() :

Html.BeginForm(ActionName , ControllerName , FormMethod.Get)
 
<% using (Html.BeginForm("SeekEmployee" , "Employer" , FormMethod.Get))
{%>
<fieldset>
<legend>Fields</legend>
Keywords:
<br />
<div class="editor-field">
<%: Html.TextBox("Keyword") %> //it should be matched the Name of the Argument of the Action
</div>
<p>
<input type="submit" value="Seek" />
</p>
</fieldset>
<% } %>

 

 
 

 

 

1.2.    Viewform control of View ( Via HTmlHelper)

 

<% using (Html.BeginForm()) {%>
<fieldset>
<legend>Fields</legend>
 
<div class="editor-label">
<%: Html.LabelFor(model => model.FirstName) %>
</div>
<div class="editor-field">
<%: Html.TextBoxFor(model => model.FirstName) %>
<%: Html.ValidationMessageFor( model => model.FirstName ,"*") %>
</div>
<p>
<input type="submit" value="Save" />
</p>
</fieldset>
<% Html.ValidationSummary(false) %>
<% } %>

 

If we dont send any parameter, the MVC will handle it for us as default value through the routing

 

Using UpdateModel and TryUpdateModel

DataContexts entities based on what the user enters can by updated by UpdateModel and TryUpdateModel

         We need try/catch for UpdateModel as it throws the errors so to avoid breaking the application , we should use the try/catch to capture the errors

         TryUpdateModel logs the error in the model state dictionary. This enables you to check the ModelState.IsValid

         explicitly invoke model binding :

(Notice that the following code is just a sample code and JobRepo is not using this approach)

public ActionResult CreateProfile(string FirstName , string LastName ,
string Phone  , string Email , string JobTitle )
{
Employee emp= null;
 
if (String.IsNullOrEmpty(FirstName))
ModelState.AddModelError("FirstName", "FirstName cannot be empty");
 
if (ModelState.IsValid)
{

// Implicit model binding operates like TryUpdateModel

// It does not throw an exception on binding failures.

}.}

White Lists and Black Lists

There are several ways to specify which fields should or should not be updated during the submission. (This can avoid any security hole. See http://www.codetunnel.com/blog/post/aspnet-mvc-model-binding-security for the potential problems)

 

1.1.    Using UpdateModel /TryUpdateModel just for White list :

 

public ViewResult UpdateProfile(FormCollection collection)
{
......
Employee emp = Context.Employee.FirstOrDefault(e => e.EmployeeID == EmployeeID);
 
UpdateModel(emp,
new String[] { "FirstName", "LastName", "Phone", "Email", "JobTitle" }
, collection);
 
if (ModelState.IsValid)
Context.SaveChanges();
......
}

 

1.2.    Using UpdateModel for both White and Black Lists:

 

public ActionResult CreateProfile(
[Bind(Include = "FirstName,LastName,Phone,Email,JobTitle", Exclude = "UserID")]Employee emp)
{
if (String.IsNullOrEmpty(emp.FirstName))
ModelState.AddModelError("FirstName", "FirstName cannot be empty");
 
if (ModelState.IsValid)
{
using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())
{
emp.UserID = Guid.Parse("3FFACAAC-00EF-49E0-BC3D-4A40435CB186");
Context.Employee.AddObject(emp);
Context.SaveChanges();
Session["EmployeeID"] = emp.EmployeeID;
return RedirectToAction("UpdateProfile");
 
}
}
return View();
}
 
 

1.3.    Using Interface + UpdateModel<T>:

In this solution, we create an interface which contains those fields which can be updated by the user and then our Entity class will implement this interface however the entity can/might have more fields.

Public interface IEntity{

String Field1{ get; Set;}

String Field2{ get; Set;}

}

Public interface MyEntity: IEntity

{String Field1{ get; Set;}

String Field2{ get; Set;}

String Field3{ get; Set;}

String Field4{ get; Set;}

}

The VIEW Should be StrongedType and it should inherit from INTERFACE ( rather than the class)

So just Field1, Field2 will be accepted through the Data Entry form /Browser

<%@ Page Title="" Language="C#" MasterPageFile="~/Views/Shared/Site.Master"

Inherits="System.Web.Mvc.ViewPage<IEntity>" %>

 

<% using (Html.BeginForm()) {%>

 

<% } %>

 

Custom Validation

1.1.    Within Model:

We can put Validation Attributes called DataAnnotations and accessible through System.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations namespace over the top of each field in out model:

         Range

         ReqularExpression

         Required

         StringLength

         Validation

Notice that if we are using, EF , WE need to create a partial class for each entity which has a MetadataType Attribute , which point to a class that behaves like an (Extra) metadata for that entity See EmployeeMetadata.cs:
 

[MetadataType(typeof(EmployeeMetadata))]

public partial class Employee

{

 

}

public class EmployeeMetadata

{

[StringLength(100)]

public string FirstName { get; set; }

 

[StringLength(100)]

public string LastName { get; set; }

}

 

 

1.2.    View:

ASP.Net 4 introduces a new syntax for writing data to the pages. It is <%: %>. This is known as code nugget syntax. The functionality is similar to <%= %>, but this do the html encoding by default. You do not worry about cross site scripting any more if you are using this.

http://weblogs.asp.net/sreejukg/archive/2010/07/28/prevent-cross-site-scripting-html-injection-attacks-with-lt.aspx

         <%: Html.ValidationMessage("LastName", "*")%>

         <%: Html.ValidationMessageFor(model => model.LastName, "*" ) %>

The field is validated based on the first argument (which is the actual name of the filed in our model ) and this method (ValidationMessage) validate the field based on validation Attributes(DataAnnotations )defined for that field

Notice that, for both we need to set the second argument which our customize message, otherwise it is showing the predefined message

1.3.    Within Controller:

If we have some custom validations which have been added through the controller like:

if (String.IsNullOrEmpty(emp.JobTitle))
ModelState.AddModelError("JobTitle", "JobTitle cannot be empty");

 

It wont be displayed on the view until having a ValidationSummary

<%: Html.ValidationSummary(false) %>

 

Notice the argument should be false and it should have a ;

Notice that there are two different approaches to call ValidationSummay:

<% Html.ValidationSummary(false); %>

<%: Html.ValidationSummary(false) %>

The first approach needs ; at the end while the second one need : at the first

Controller with dependency to other classes via its constructor

public interface IKeywordsPopularity
{
void SetAsPopular(string Keyword);
}
public class SQLServerKeywordsPopularity :IKeywordsPopularity
{
public void SetAsPopular(string Keyword)
{
using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())
{
Context.SetKeywordsPopularity(Keyword);
}
}
}

 

Solutions:

1.1.    The first solution is creating a custom controller which is responsible to instantiate all dependency so the code will be as below:

 

public class JobRepoControllerFactory : DefaultControllerFactory

{

protected override IController GetControllerInstance (System.Web.Routing.RequestContext requestContext, Type controllerType)

{

return Activator.CreateInstance(controllerType, new SQLServerKeywordsPopularity()) as IController;

}

}

 

And: 
 
public class EmployerController: Controller
{
IKeywordsPopularity _KeywordsPopularity;
public EmployerController(IKeywordsPopularity KeywordsPopularity)
{
_KeywordsPopularity = KeywordsPopularity;
}
.
 
And then we should register our ControllerFactory:
 
protected void Application_Start()
{
AreaRegistration.RegisterAllAreas();
 
RegisterRoutes(RouteTable.Routes);
 
ControllerBuilder.Current.SetControllerFactory(new JobRepoControllerFactory());
}

 

But the issue with this solution is that if JobRepoControllerFactory is used by any requested controller so if the controller doesnt have any dependency and its constructor doesnt accept any argument , the application will be failed during the execution

1.2.    Using Injection Dependency:

We are using Unity framework for implementing Injection Dependency:

public class EmployerController : Controller
{
IKeywordsPopularity _KeywordsPopularity;
public EmployerController(IKeywordsPopularity KeywordsPopularity)
{
_KeywordsPopularity = KeywordsPopularity;
}
 
// GET: /Employer/
public ActionResult SeekEmployee(string keyword)
{
_KeywordsPopularity.SetAsPopular(keyword);
 
return View();
}
}
 
Now we need to use one of injection Dependency Tools like: UNITY, Mikrokrenel , StructureMap or NInject (all are free)
Here we are using Unity.MV3
http://www.devtrends.co.uk/blog/integrating-the-unity.mvc3-1.1-nuget-package-from-scratch
http://www.devtrends.co.uk/blog/introducing-the-unity.mvc3-nuget-package-to-reconcile-mvc3-unity-and-idisposable
 
http://unitymvc3.codeplex.com/SourceControl/changeset/view/580f45a682a5e6101051c161dfd82baeda58ede1#Unity.Mvc3.Example/Global.asax.cs
 
By installing this tool through Nuget , It generates all codes and file we need, the only things which we need to add/change are:
 

1.2.1. In the generate BootStapper file by Unity.MV3 , we should register all DEPENDENCY components ( notice that just Dependency components are enough) so:

 
private static IUnityContainer BuildUnityContainer()
{
var container = new UnityContainer();
 
// register all your components with the container here
// it is NOT necessary to register your controllers
 
container.RegisterType<IKeywordsPopularity, SQLServerKeywordsPopularity>();
 
return container;
}
 
 

1.2.2. In Application_Start , the following code should be added

 

protected void Application_Start()
{
 
 
// We are using Injection Dependency rathe than using custom ControllerFactory for
// those controllers which have dependency to the other classes and types
// ControllerBuilder.Current.SetControllerFactory(new JobRepoControllerFactory());
Bootstrapper.Initialise();
}
 
So now the controller can be used like other controller

Adding HTTPModule

Be default we need to modify the web.config and register the module though the config file but in .NET 4.0, there is a new way to do that WITHOOUT touching the web config file.

1.1.    In AssemblyInfo.cs , we should add PreApplicationStartMethod as below:

 
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
 
 

 

 
 

1.2.    Create a class named PreApplicationStartCode and put this following code within this class:

 

using Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure.DynamicModuleHelper;
 
namespace MyProjectNamespace
{
public class PreApplicationStartCode
{
private static bool _isStarting;
 
public static void PreStart()
{
if (!_isStarting)
{
_isStarting = true;
 
DynamicModuleUtility.RegisterModule(typeof(MyHttpModule));
}
}
}
}

 

MyHttpModule is the module written by us.

Custom HtmlHelper

Non-Strong Types Custom HtmlHelper

Asking the file path from the user and then the system uploads the file from the requested path:

 

Model:

namespace JobRepoMVC.Models

{

 

public class FileModel

{

[Required]

public string FileName { get; set; }

public string Description { get; set; }

}

}

 

 

Customer HtmlHelper:

namespace JobRepoMVC.Controls

{

public static class FileUploadHelper

{

 

public static string FileUploader(this HtmlHelper htmlHelper, string filename, IDictionary<String, Object> htmlAttributes)

{

 

var tagBuilder = new TagBuilder("input");

tagBuilder.MergeAttributes(htmlAttributes);

tagBuilder.MergeAttribute("type", "file", true);

tagBuilder.MergeAttribute("name", filename, true);

tagBuilder.GenerateId(filename);

 

ModelState modelState;

if (htmlHelper.ViewData.ModelState.TryGetValue(filename, out modelState))

{

if (modelState.Errors.Count > 0)

{

tagBuilder.AddCssClass(HtmlHelper.ValidationInputCssClassName);

}

}

 

return tagBuilder.ToString(TagRenderMode.SelfClosing);

}

 

public static string FileUploader(this HtmlHelper helper, string filename)

{

return helper.FileUploader(filename, (object) null);

 

}

 

public static string FileUploader(this HtmlHelper htmlHelper, string filename, object htmlAttributes)

{

return htmlHelper.FileUploader(filename, new RouteValueDictionary(htmlAttributes));

}

}

}

Notice those two parameters  FormMethod.Post, new { enctype = "multipart/form-data" } should be set as above if we want to be able to send a file from the browser to the server

 
Notice that, after merging ASP.NET MVC application to ASP.NET application, the above code didnt work
, new { enctype = "multipart/form-data" } should be within just one <Form> , however , since the view was inherited from SiteUnauthenticated.Master and SiteUnauthenticated.Master has its own <form> so we have two nested forms and enctype="multipatr/form-data" attribute on your inner form you were getting the wrong Request.ContentType
See here for more details http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8159725/mvc-httppostedfilebase-is-always-null
So fix this problem, a new master page which doesnt have any form inside has been created and View UploadResume has been inherited from the new master page
 
 

Controller:

[AcceptVerbs(HttpVerbs.Post)]

public ActionResult UploadResume(FileModel model)

{

int EmployeeID = Session["EmployeeID"] == null ? 0 : Convert.ToInt32(Session["EmployeeID"]);

if (EmployeeID > 0 && ModelState.IsValid)

{

 

byte[] uploadedfile = new byte[model.File.ContentLength];

if (uploadedfile.Length > 0)

{

HttpPostedFileBase file = model.File;

file.InputStream.Read(uploadedfile, 0, (int)model.File.ContentLength);

 

 

using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())

{

 

Resume entity = new Resume()

{

Title = model.Title,

PostedDate = DateTime.Now,

Description = uploadedfile,

Keywords = model.Keywords,

EmployeeID = EmployeeID

};

Context.Resume.AddObject(entity);

Context.SaveChanges();

}

}

 

return RedirectToAction("ManageResumes");

 

}

return View();

}

 

<%= %> is shortcut for Response.write but in ASP.NET there is new tag (<%:) which has the same behavior ( i.e. writes out to the page) but with one more feature which is HTML encoded

So

<%: = <%= %> + HTML encoded

notice that after creating the custom HtmlHelper , we cannot use <%: as it will print out the tage as plain Text rather than render a CONTROL!!! So we still need to use <=

<%= Html.FileUploader("FileName") %>

 

Strong Types Custom HtmlHelper

 

View:

<%-- Non-Strong typed      --%>

<%= Html.FileUploader(m => m.File, new { type = "file" })%>

 

Controller:

//See here for more details:http://20fingers2brains.blogspot.com.au/2013/05/custom-password-html-helper-with-model.html

//This overload accepts expression and htmlAttributes object as parameter.

public static MvcHtmlString FileUploader<TModel, TValue>(this HtmlHelper<TModel> helper, Expression<Func<TModel, TValue>> expression, object htmlAttributes)

{

//Fetching the metadata related to expression. This includes name of the property, model value of the property as well.

ModelMetadata metadata = ModelMetadata.FromLambdaExpression(expression, helper.ViewData);

 

string htmlFieldName = ExpressionHelper.GetExpressionText(expression);

 

//Fetching the property name.

string propertyName = metadata.DisplayName ?? metadata.PropertyName ?? htmlFieldName.Split('.').Last();

 

 

//Creating a textarea tag using TagBuilder class.

var tagBuilder = new TagBuilder("input");

 

//Setting the name and id attribute.

tagBuilder.Attributes.Add("name", propertyName);

tagBuilder.Attributes.Add("id", propertyName);

 

 

// This part is not applicable because:

//1-  The value here is the actual file which is a binary value not a string

//2- This control is always empty when the page is rendered so it doesnt have any default or initilized value

//Setting the value attribute of textbox with model value if present.

//if (metadata.Model != null)

//{

//    tagBuilder.Attributes.Add("value", metadata.Model.ToString());

//}

 

//merging any htmlAttributes passed.

tagBuilder.MergeAttributes(new RouteValueDictionary(htmlAttributes));

 

return MvcHtmlString.Create(tagBuilder.ToString(TagRenderMode.Normal));

}

As you see it accept an Expression<Func<TModel, TValue>>

 

Partial View

They can be very useful when they are used by AJAX so that portions of the page will be rendered but a simple example can be as below ( notice that the following sample doesnt use AJAX yet)

 

View:

<% if (Model !=null )  foreach (var item in Model) { %>

<%--

<tr>

<td><%: Html.ActionLink("See Details", "Details", new { id = item.EmployeeID }) %></td>

<td>

<%: item.FirstName %>

</td>

<td>

<%: item.LastName %>

</td>

<td>

<%: item.JobTitle %>

</td>

</tr>--%>

 

<%--Using PartialView rather than HTML raw table(above) :--%>

<% Html.RenderPartial("EmployeeDetail", item); %>

<% } %>

Notice that for String.Format is using the default culture ( thread.culture , thread.UICulture) but if we want to have a dynamic setting and if we want to set the culture based on HTTP header , the following code should be added to the web.config:

<system.web>

<globalization culture="auto" uiCulture="auto"/>

 

So if we changed the current culture of WINDOWS to French , the String .Format will show the data based on the selected/newculture

Notes:

1.1.    Having an ActionLink with a confirmation Message :

column.For(c => Html.ActionLink("Delete", "DeleteResume", new { id = c.ResumeID } ,

Custom Binder

It works and behaves like Convertor in Silverlight

The following steps should be done:

1.1.    Create a custom Binder class:

namespace JobRepoMVC.Binders

{

public class DateTimeModelBinder :IModelBinder

{

public object BindModel(ControllerContext controllerContext, ModelBindingContext bindingContext)

{

ValueProviderResult result;

result = bindingContext.ValueProvider.GetValue(bindingContext.ModelName);

if (result == null)

return null;

 

bindingContext.ModelState.SetModelValue(bindingContext.ModelName, result);

 

DateTime datetimeresult;

if (DateTime.TryParse(result.AttemptedValue, out datetimeresult))

{

return datetimeresult;

}

 

int intresult;

if (int.TryParse(result.AttemptedValue, out intresult))

{

return new DateTime(intresult, 1, 1);

}

 

bindingContext.ModelState.AddModelError(bindingContext.ModelName , "Could not convert data to datetime");

return null;

}

}

}

 

Notice:

Refer to http://ivanz.com/2010/11/03/custom-model-binding-using-imodelbinder-in-asp-net-mvc-two-gotchas/

1.1.1. If your binding validation fails you should log an appropriate validation error via ModelState.AddModelError . It is useful to know that if you add exceptions of type FormatException to the model errors, ASP.NET MVC is smart enough to automatically convert them to string errors post-binding but before it returns control to your controller action.

1.1.2. If you log an error you must call ModelState.SetModelValue or otherwise if you return null it will cause a NullReferenceException in the default ASP.NET MVC binder. This is so because unless you call that method the rest of the ASP.NET MVC code (as well as your own code) wont be able to access ModelState[propertyName] and because it doesnt handle that it blows up

private void RegisterModelBinders()

{

}

protected void Application_Start()

{

.

RegisterModelBinders();

 

..

}

1.4.    Inheriting from DafaultModelBinder rather than ImodelBinder

public class DateTimeModelBinder: DefaultModelBinder// :IModelBinder
{
public DateTimeModelBinder()
{
 
}
public override object BindModel(ControllerContext controllerContext, ModelBindingContext bindingContext)
{
ValueProviderResult result;
result = bindingContext.ValueProvider.GetValue(bindingContext.ModelName);
if (result == null)
return null;
 
bindingContext.ModelState.SetModelValue(bindingContext.ModelName, result);
 
DateTime datetimeresult;
if (DateTime.TryParse(result.AttemptedValue, out datetimeresult))
{
return "Hello";
}
 
int intresult;
if (int.TryParse(result.AttemptedValue, out intresult))
{
return "Bye";
//return new DateTime(intresult, 1, 1);
}
 
bindingContext.ModelState.AddModelError(bindingContext.ModelName, "Could not convert data to datetime");
return null;
}
}

Url.Content():

when we adding Scripts or css files to a page , we can use Url.Content() + ~
to make sure , the browser recognize the correct path so for example the following <Script>

<script src="../../Scripts/jquery.dataTables.js" type="text/javascript"></script>

 

Can be changed to:

<script src="<%= Url.Content("~/Scripts/jquery.dataTables.js") %>" type="text/javascript"></script>
 
Notice that you need ~/ otherwise the browser cannot recognize the absolute path

Controller(Index.aspx):

public class SelectedEmployeeController : Controller

{

//

// GET: /SelectedEmployee/

public ActionResult Index(string keyword = "")

{

string[] filters = keyword.Split(';');

 

List<Employee> emps = null;

int EmployerID = Session["EmployerID"] == null ? 0 : Convert.ToInt32(Session["EmployerID"]);

using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())

{

if (keyword != "")

emps = (from sel in Context.SelectedEmployee.Where(e => e.EmployerID == EmployerID)

join emp in Context.Employee on sel.EmployeeID equals emp.EmployeeID

join res in Context.Resume.Where(p => filters.Any(x => p.Keywords.Contains(x))) on emp.EmployeeID equals res.EmployeeID

select emp).Distinct().ToList();

else

emps = (from sel in Context.SelectedEmployee.Where(e => e.EmployerID == EmployerID)

join emp in Context.Employee on sel.EmployeeID equals emp.EmployeeID

join res in Context.Resume on emp.EmployeeID equals res.EmployeeID

select emp).Distinct().ToList();

 

if (Request.IsAjaxRequest())

{

return PartialView("_AjaxEnabledSelectedEmployee", emps);

}

 

return View("Index", emps);

}

}

 

}

Notice that the first time the request IS NOT Ajax request so the if is valid so it return View("Index", emps); Will be executed but for further requests , IF will be true so

return PartialView("_AjaxEnabledSelectedEmployee", emps); will be executed and the only part of page index.aspx which will be updated and re-rendered is

 

<div id="SearchResult" >

<% Html.RenderPartial("_AjaxEnabledSelectedEmployee", Model); %>

</div>

Control:

public class KeywordPopularityController : Controller

{

//

// GET: /KeywordPopularity/

 

public ActionResult KeywordPopularity()

{

return View();

}

 

 

 

public JsonResult Keywords()

{

object Keywords = null;

using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())

{

Keywords = (from i in Context.KeywordPopularity.Select(e => e.Keyword).Distinct()

select new

{

ID = i,

Name = i

}).ToList();

}

return Json(Keywords, JsonRequestBehavior.AllowGet);

 

}

 

 

 

public JsonResult KeywordCount(string Keyword)

{

object res = null;

using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())

{

res = Context.KeywordPopularity.Where(e => e.Keyword.Contains(Keyword)).ToList();

}

 

return Json(res, JsonRequestBehavior.AllowGet);

 

}

 

}

 

Notice that the second parameter for json() should be set if the type of action is Get ( by default is POST)

JavaScript(File):

/// <reference path="jquery-1.4.1-vsdoc.js" />

/// <reference path="jquery.validate-vsdoc.js" />

 

$().ready(function () {

 

$.getJSON("/KeywordPopularity/Keywords", "", function (data) {

$(data).each(function () {

$('<option>').val(this.ID).text(this.Name)

.appendTo('#SelectKeyword');

});

 

});

 

 

$("#SelectKeyword").change(function () {

 

var val = $("#SelectKeyword").val();

//if (parseInt(val)) {

if (val != "") {

$.getJSON("/KeywordPopularity/KeywordCount/", { Keyword: val }, function (data) {

 

var list = $("<ul></ul>");

$(data).each(function () {

 

$("<li>" + this.Keyword +  " <br /> Popularity : " + this.Count + "</li> <br /> ").appendTo(list);

});

 

$("#KeywordPopularityCount").html(list);

});

}

});

});

 

Notice that Parseint() has not been used in this function as the method needs an string arg not an int arg but Parseint() can be used to check if the user has selected something and it not the default option which is empty

 

Notice that passing parameter to the method shoule be in JSon format e.g.:

{ key:value , Key:value ,.} like { Keyword: val }

WCF Service and jQuery and AJAX

Approach #1:

The Action method can be a services method rather than being a method in Controller , to do so:

Removing from Controller adding the following Service with the same method:

Controller:

//This method has been moved to the PopularityService

//public JsonResult KeywordCount(string Keyword)

Service Interface:

[ServiceContract]

interface IKeywordService

{

[OperationContract]

List<KeywordPopularityDTO> KeywordCount(string Keyword);

}

 

Service:

namespace JobRepoMVC.Services

{

// NOTE: You can use the "Rename" command on the "Refactor" menu to change the interface name "IKeywordService" in both code and config file together.

[AspNetCompatibilityRequirements(RequirementsMode = AspNetCompatibilityRequirementsMode.Allowed)]

public class KeywordService : JobRepoMVC.Services.IKeywordService

{

public List<KeywordPopularityDTO> KeywordCount(string Keyword)

{

List<KeywordPopularityDTO> res = null;

using (JobRepoDataContext Context = new JobRepoDataContext())

{

res = (from i in Context.KeywordPopularity.Where(e => e.Keyword.Contains(Keyword))

select new KeywordPopularityDTO { Keyword = i.Keyword , Count = i.Count })

.ToList();

}

 

return res;

 

}

}

 

Notice that Entity object (Entity framework object) cannot be used with WCF directly as Entity Framework doesnt support WCF serialization by default, to do so, one of the solutions can be using DTO which contains [DataContract] and [Data Member]:

 

[DataContract]

public class KeywordPopularityDTO

{

[DataMember]

public string Keyword { get; set; }

[DataMember]

public int Count { get; set; }    }

<system.serviceModel>

<behaviors>

<endpointBehaviors>

<enableWebScript/>

</behavior>

</endpointBehaviors>

<serviceBehaviors>

<behavior name="">

<serviceMetadata httpGetEnabled="true" />

<serviceDebug includeExceptionDetailInFaults="false" />

</behavior>

</serviceBehaviors>

</behaviors>

<serviceHostingEnvironment multipleSiteBindingsEnabled="true" aspNetCompatibilityEnabled="true" />

<services>

<service name="JobRepoMVC.Services.KeywordService">

<endpoint address="" behaviorConfiguration="JobRepoMVC.Services.KeywordServiceAspnetAjaxBehavior"

binding="webHttpBinding" contract="JobRepoMVC.Services.IKeywordService">

 

</endpoint>

</service>

</services>

</system.serviceModel>

Cassini

1.2.    IIS7 introduced an Integrated pipeline , Integrated pipeline means the IIS Pipeline and ASP.NET pipeline have been integrated so we can use the feature of both together

A website contains one or more application and each application can contain one or more virtual directories and each virtual directory points to a physical path

 

OUTPUT Cache

Which means cashing HTML output and to do so , we need to use an attribute for out action:
 
[OutputCache(Duration = 30, VaryByParam = "Keyword")]
public PartialViewResult KeywordCount(string Keyword)
{
IKeywordService service = new KeywordService();
return PartialView("_AJAXEnabledServicedKeywordCount", service.KeywordCount(Keyword));
}
 
Notice VaryByParam  can be none which means always cache the same content , * means cache for every permutation of all paramteres or can be based on a name of parameter like the above example
 

Notice that * is not recommeneded because by using that , everything will be cached on the server , they will use a lot of memory and resource of the server so the performance will go down rather than going up

 

Notice that we can use a cache profile as below :

 

[OutputCache(CacheProfile = MyProfile, VaryByParam = "Keyword")]

 

And in the config file we have:
 

<caching>

<outputCacheSettings>

<outputCacheProfiles>

<add name="myprofile" enabled="true" duration="60"/>

</outputCacheProfiles>

</outputCacheSettings>

</caching>

 

 

Donut Cache(Substitution cache)

Notice that VaryByParam="None" means caching everything in the page but if we want to cache everything execpt a particalu area , we should use
 

<% Response.WriteSubstitution(ctx => DateTime.Now.ToLongTimeString()); %>

 
 
We can create a Html helper like this:
 

public delegate string MvcCacheCallback(HttpContextBase context);

public static object Substitute(this HtmlHelper html, MvcCacheCallback cb) {

html.ViewContext.HttpContext.Response.WriteSubstitution(

c => HttpUtility.HtmlEncode(

cb(new HttpContextWrapper(c))

));

return null;

}
 
And then we can use it like this:
 

<% Response.Substitute(ctx => DateTime.Now.ToLongTimeString()); %>

HTTPContext.cache.Insert (key , data , .)
 
Can be retrived by :

1.4.    We can use Cache,but the problem with cache is that it is global object and it can be change and overwritten by any user using the application

1.5.    Using Session but The problem is that we have to clean session after use so maybe several places we have to write the line of code to clean the session

1.6.    Put in the cookie: but Notice that the value of cookie will go and save on the client machine so it is not forsensitive data and also after sneeding to the client for any further request from client , it will be sent back to the server

1.7.    MVC Tempdata:Actually it is using Session and It is available for one request So it is like a one request session object . it will be cleaned automatically

So it can be used like this

TempData[XX] = YY;

But TempData is not accible in View so in out action , whenever we want to send TEmpdatas data to the view , we should send it through viewdata like:

 

Public ActionResult Index()

{

 

ViewData{XX] = TempData[XX];

.

Return View();

}

1.15.MVC master page should be inherited from the existing ASP.NET master page:

<%@ Master Language="C#" Inherits="System.Web.Mvc.ViewMasterPage"  MasterPageFile="~/SiteUnauthenticated.Master" %>

 
 

1.16.If we want to move all links , scripts , registered from the MVC master page to ASP.NET master page, the following changws should be applied :

 
Notice that since ASP.NET master page , unlike MVC master page , cannot inherits from System.Web.Mvc.ViewMasterPag so we cannot use
<script src="<%= Url.Content("~/Scripts/jquery.dataTables.js") %>" type="text/javascript"></script>
 
So instead we should use the original version:
<script src="~/Scripts/jquery.dataTables.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
 
And also we cannot use ../../scripts or ../../Content all should be changed to:
~/Scriptsand "~/Content/ so in SiteUnauthenticated.master we have:
<script src="~/Scripts/MicrosoftAjax.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
<script src="~/Scripts/MicrosoftMvcAjax.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
<link href="~/Content/Site.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
<script src="~/Scripts/jquery-1.7.min.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
<script src="~/Scripts/jquery.dataTables.js" type="text/javascript"></script>
<link href="~/Content/jquery.dataTables.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
 
 
However, we can keep those links and refs within MVC master page, as long as they are within ContentPlaceHolderIDs header inherited from the parent master page

Security Locking a path in ASP.NET MVC

 

It is possible to lock or limited some pages by using <location> in web.condig like:

<location path="JobList.aspx">

<system.web>

<authorization>

<deny users="?" />

</authorization>

</system.web>

</location>

However, we CANNOT do the something in MVC
 
You cannot use routing or web.config files to secure your MVC application (Any Version). The only supported way to secure your MVC application is to apply the Authorize attribute... MVC uses routes and does not map URLs to physical file locations like WebForms, PHP and traditional web servers. Therefore using web.config will definitely open a security hole in your site.
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11765030/how-to-lock-down-paths-in-asp-net-mvc-4 for more details
 

[Authorize]

To secure a page(action) we should use [Authorize]:

 

namespace JobRepo.MVC.Controllers

{

public class SelectedEmployeeController : Controller

{

//

// GET: /SelectedEmployee/

[Authorize]

public ActionResult List(string keyword = "")

{

..

Apply filter on Action or Controller

 

To do that a new attribute which has been inherited from ActionFilterAttribute should be created
 
Filter:

public class LoggedAsEmployeeActionFilter : ActionFilterAttribute

{

public override void OnActionExecuting(ActionExecutingContext filterContext)

{

if (filterContext.HttpContext.User.Identity == null)

{

filterContext.Result = new RedirectToRouteResult(new RouteValueDictionary(new

{

controller = "Home",

action = "Login",

message ="Please Log in to access this page "

}));

}

else

{

int EmployeeID = filterContext.HttpContext.Session["EmployeeID"] == null ? 0 : Convert.ToInt32(filterContext.HttpContext.Session["EmployeeID"]);

int EmployerID = filterContext.HttpContext.Session["EmployerID"] == null ? 0 : Convert.ToInt32(filterContext.HttpContext.Session["EmployerID"]);

if (EmployeeID <= 0)

{

if (EmployeeID <= 0)

{

filterContext.Result = new RedirectToRouteResult(new RouteValueDictionary(new

{

controller = "Home",

action = "Login",

message = "Please Log in to access this page "

}));

}

else

{

filterContext.Result = new RedirectToRouteResult(new RouteValueDictionary(new

{

controller = "Home",

action = "Login",

message = "Please use different account to access this page"

}));

}

}

}

 

}

}

 

Notice that it handles Authorization as well so we can remove [Authorize] which we had put for some of Actions
 
Notice that this Attribute can be put at the top of an action or at the top of Controller like:
 
Action:
 

//[Authorize]

[LoggedAsEmployeeActionFilter]

public ActionResult ManageResumes()

{
.
}

Controller:

 

[LoggedAsEmployerActionFilter]

public class SelectedEmployeeController : Controller

{

//

// GET: /SelectedEmployee/

//[Authorize]

public ActionResult List(string keyword = "")

{

{
.
}
.
}
 

Notice that if it is used by a controller, it will be applied for all actions inside that controller.
